quotes.topic_title: Test-everything mindset and expected failure rates
quotes.text: I'm very clear that I'm a big fan of test everything, which is any code change that you make, any feature that you introduce has to be in some experiment.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A clear operational rule-of-thumb: treat every change as an experiment to systematically manage product risk and learning.

quotes.topic_title: Test-everything mindset and expected failure rates
quotes.text: Because again, I've observed this sort of surprising result that even small bug fixes, even small changes can sometimes have surprising, unexpected impact.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that “safe” small changes can still move key metrics, so they deserve measurement.

quotes.topic_title: Test-everything mindset and expected failure rates
quotes.text: And so I don't think it's possible to experiment too much.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Pushes against the common fear of over-testing by advocating for a high cadence of experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Test-everything mindset and expected failure rates
quotes.text: We're going to try something that's most likely to fail. But if it does win, it's going to be a home run.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A portfolio mindset for experimentation: accept likely failures to access occasional outsized wins.

quotes.topic_title: Test-everything mindset and expected failure rates
quotes.text: If you go for something big, try it out, but be ready to fail 80% of the time.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Sets an explicit expected failure rate to help teams calibrate morale, planning, and decision-making around big bets.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we get super tactical about A/B testing.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets the expectation that the episode will focus on practical, implementable experimentation guidance rather than theory.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Ronny shares his advice for when you should start considering running experiments at your company, how to change your company's culture to be more experiment driven, what are signs your experiments are potentially invalid, why trust is the most important element of a successful experiment, culture, and platform.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights key practitioner-relevant themes: when to start, culture change, validity checks, and the primacy of trust in experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: He also explains what actually is a P value and something called Twyman's law, plus some hot takes about Airbnb and experiments in general.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals that the episode will cover core statistical concepts and a named law that can shape how practitioners interpret experimental results.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This episode is for anyone who's interested in either creating an experiment driven culture at their company or just fine-tuning one that already exists.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames experimentation as an organizational capability (culture) that can be built or improved, not just a set of analyses.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Get deep insights into what your users are doing at every stage of the funnel, at a fair price that scales at you grow.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable goal for analytics tooling: full-funnel visibility with pricing that scales with the business.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And by capturing website activity, ad data, and multi-touch attribution right in Mixpanel, you can improve every aspect of the full user funnel.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Suggests a practical methodology: unify behavioral + marketing + attribution data in one place to optimize the entire funnel.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Powered by first party behavioral data instead of third party cookies, Mixpanel is built to be more powerful and easier to use than Google Analytics.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian positioning that emphasizes first-party behavioral data as a stronger foundation than third-party cookies.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Leading in tech is uniquely challenging, and doing it well is easiest when surrounded by leaders who understand your day-to-day experiences.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable leadership advice: accelerate growth by building a peer network with shared context and challenges.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Building and managing your network doesn't have to feel like networking.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that challenges the conventional view of networking as transactional or performative.

quotes.topic_title: Surprising wins: tiny UI change, huge revenue
quotes.text: But the point about this is it's trivial to implement. So if you think about return on investment, we could get the data by having some engineers spend a couple of hours implementing it.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A practical ROI heuristic: prioritize experiments that are cheap to build because learning value can be high even when the idea seems “meh.”

quotes.topic_title: Surprising wins: tiny UI change, huge revenue
quotes.text: That simple idea increased revenue by about 12%.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing how a tiny UI change can drive outsized business impact.

quotes.topic_title: Surprising wins: tiny UI change, huge revenue
quotes.text: And the key thing is it didn't hurt the user metrics. So it's very easy to increase revenue by doing theatrics. Displaying more ads is a trivial way to raise revenue, but it hurts the user experience.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Highlights the guardrail-metrics mindset: revenue wins aren’t enough unless core user experience metrics stay healthy.

quotes.topic_title: Surprising wins: tiny UI change, huge revenue
quotes.text: But to me, this was an example of a tiny change that was the best revenue generating idea in Bing's history, and we didn't rate it properly.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Counterintuitive lesson about prioritization: teams systematically under-rank high-impact ideas when relying on intuition.

quotes.topic_title: Surprising wins: tiny UI change, huge revenue
quotes.text: When you have winners, make sure to address them and remember them.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Actionable advice on institutional memory: codify and preserve learnings from successful experiments so they don’t get “semi forgotten.”

quotes.topic_title: How often big wins happen and why most fail
quotes.text: But as you said, they're very rare. I think most of the time, the winnings are made this inch by inch.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Reframes experimentation success as compounding incremental gains rather than hunting for rare “big wins.”

quotes.topic_title: How often big wins happen and why most fail
quotes.text: They have a metric, we'll talk about OEC, the overall evaluation criterion. But they have a metric that their goal is to improve it by 2% every year. It's a small amount, and that 2% you can see here's a 0.1, and here's a 0.15, here's a 0.2, and then they add up to around 2% every year, which is amazing.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Offers a concrete goal-setting model: target small, measurable lifts that accumulate into meaningful annual impact.

quotes.topic_title: How often big wins happen and why most fail
quotes.text: Another example that I am allowed to speak about from Airbnb is the fact that we ran some 250 experiments in my tenure there in search relevance. And again, small improvements added up. So this became overall a 6% improvement to revenue. So when you think about 6%, it's a big number, but it came out not of one idea, but many, many smaller ideas that each gave you a small gain.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Quantifies how high experiment volume plus small wins can translate into material revenue gains.

quotes.topic_title: How often big wins happen and why most fail
quotes.text: Well, first of all, I published three different numbers for my career. So overall at Microsoft, about 66%, two thirds of ideas fail. And don't think the 66 is accurate. It's about two thirds. At Bing, which is a much more optimized domain after we've been optimizing it for a while, the failure rate was around 85%. So it's harder to improve something that you've been optimizing for a while. And then at Airbnb, this 92% number is the highest failure rate that I've observed.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Sets realistic expectations for experimentation: failure rates rise as products become more optimized, making wins harder.

quotes.topic_title: How often big wins happen and why most fail
quotes.text: So it's possible that when you have an idea, your first implementation, you start an experiment. Boom, it's egregiously bad, because you have a bug. In fact, 10% of experiments tend to be aborted on the first date. Those are usually not that the idea is bad, but that there is an implementation issue or something we haven't thought about, that forces an abort.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Clarifies that “failed experiments” often reflect execution/quality issues (e.g., bugs) rather than bad ideas—important for interpreting failure metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Reusable patterns and institutional learning systems
quotes.text: In general, by the way, a lot of that is institutional memory, which is can you document things well enough so that the organization remembers the successes and failures, and learns from them?
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A practical framing of experimentation as an institutional-memory problem, not just a testing problem.

quotes.topic_title: Reusable patterns and institutional learning systems
quotes.text: I think one of the mistakes that some company makes is they launch a lot of experiments and never go back and summarize the learnings. So I've actually put a lot of effort in this idea of institutional learning, of doing the quarterly meeting of the most surprising experiments.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Actionable operating cadence: quarterly reviews to turn many experiments into durable learning and culture.

quotes.topic_title: Reusable patterns and institutional learning systems
quotes.text: To me, a surprising experiment is one where the estimated result beforehand and the actual result differ by a lot. So that absolute value of the difference is large.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A clear definition/metric for “surprise” that teams can use to prioritize which experiments to review and learn from.

quotes.topic_title: Reusable patterns and institutional learning systems
quotes.text: So we focused not just on the winners, but also surprising losers, things that people thought would be a no-brainer to run. And then for some reason, it was very negative. And sometimes, it's that negative that gives you insight.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Counterintuitive learning strategy: mine unexpected failures (not just wins) for the biggest insights.

quotes.topic_title: Reusable patterns and institutional learning systems
quotes.text: Document it. We had a large deck internally of these successes and failures, and we encourage people to look at them. The other thing that's very beneficial is just to have your whole history of experiments and do some ability to search by keywords.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Concrete practices for institutional memory: documentation plus a searchable experiment archive to prevent relearning the same lessons.

quotes.topic_title: Can experimentation hinder innovation? Portfolio approach
quotes.text: I'm very clear that I'm a big fan of test everything, which is any code change that you make, any feature that you introduce has to be in some experiment.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A strong operational principle: default to experimentation for every change to avoid hidden negative impacts.

quotes.topic_title: Can experimentation hinder innovation? Portfolio approach
quotes.text: And so I don't think it's possible to experiment too much. I think it is possible to focus on incremental changes because some people say, "Well, if we only tested 17 things around this," you have to think about, it's like in stock. You need a portfolio.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Introduces a portfolio mental model to balance incremental optimizations with bigger bets.

quotes.topic_title: Can experimentation hinder innovation? Portfolio approach
quotes.text: But some experiments, you have to allocate sometimes to these high risk, high reward ideas. We're going to try something that's most likely to fail, but if it does win, it's going to be a home run.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on explicitly reserving capacity for high-variance experiments rather than only safe iterations.

quotes.topic_title: Can experimentation hinder innovation? Portfolio approach
quotes.text: Hey, if you go for something big, try it out, but be ready to fail 80% of the time.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A memorable expectation-setting heuristic for radical innovation: most big bets should be expected to fail.

quotes.topic_title: Can experimentation hinder innovation? Portfolio approach
quotes.text:
So we hooked into the Twitter fire hose feed and we hooked into Facebook, and we spent 100 person years on this idea.

And it failed.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Concrete example and data point showing that even massive investments can fail—and why experimentation is needed to detect it.

quotes.topic_title: When not to A/B test and when to start
quotes.text: First of all, there are some necessary ingredients to A/B testing. And I'll just say outright, not every domain is amenable to A/B testing. You can't A/B test mergers and acquisitions. It's something that happens once, you either acquire or you don't acquire.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Clarifies a key boundary condition: experimentation requires repeatable units, so some high-stakes one-off decisions simply aren’t testable.

quotes.topic_title: When not to A/B test and when to start
quotes.text: I don't say it's easy to build a platform. But once you build a platform, the incremental cost of running an experiment should approach zero. And we got to that at Microsoft, where after a while, the cost of running experiments was so low that nobody was questioning the idea that everything should be experimented with.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Offers a scalable operating model: invest in experimentation infrastructure until marginal experiment cost is near-zero, enabling “experiment everything.”

quotes.topic_title: When not to A/B test and when to start
quotes.text: one of the things I show there is that unless you have at least tens of thousands of users, the math, the statistics just don't work out for most of the metrics that you're interested in.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Gives a practical threshold for startups: below tens of thousands of users, most A/B tests won’t have enough statistical power to be useful.

quotes.topic_title: When not to A/B test and when to start
quotes.text: They shouldn't focus on the 1%, they should focus on the 5 and 10%. Then you need something like 200,000 users.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prioritization rule plus a concrete sample-size benchmark: early teams should target big wins, and meaningful detection often needs ~200k users.

quotes.topic_title: When not to A/B test and when to start
quotes.text: So start experimenting when you're in the tens of thousands of users. You'll only be able to detect large effects. And then once you get to 200,000 users, then the magic starts happening.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Provides a simple rule-of-thumb roadmap for when experimentation becomes increasingly powerful as user scale grows.

quotes.topic_title: OEC: optimizing for long-term user value
quotes.text: The OEC or the overall evaluation criterion is something that I think many people that start to dabble in A/B testing miss. And the question is, what are you optimizing for? And it's a much harder question that people think because it's very easy to say we're going to optimize for money, revenue. But that's the wrong question, because you can do a lot of bad things that will improve revenue. So there has to be some countervailing metric that tells you, how do I improve revenue without hurting the user experience?
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Defines OEC as a discipline of pairing revenue goals with explicit user-experience counter-metrics to prevent short-term hacks.

quotes.topic_title: OEC: optimizing for long-term user value
quotes.text: We've run those experiments, and we were able to map out this number of ads causes this much increase to churn, this number of ads causes this much increase to the time that users take to find a successful result. And we came up with an OEC that is based on all these metrics that allows you to say, "Okay, I'm willing to take this additional money if I'm not hurting the user experience by more than this much." So there's a trade-off there.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Shows a concrete method: quantify UX harm (churn, time-to-success) and encode an explicit trade-off threshold in the OEC.

quotes.topic_title: OEC: optimizing for long-term user value
quotes.text: One of the nice ways to phrase this, as a constraint optimization problem. I want you to increase revenue, but I'm going to give you a fixed amount of average real estate that you can use.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Offers a memorable mental model: optimize revenue subject to hard constraints (e.g., ad pixels) to protect long-term experience.

quotes.topic_title: OEC: optimizing for long-term user value
quotes.text: To me, the key word is lifetime value, which is you have to define the OEC such that it is causally predictive of the lifetime value of the user.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Gives a practical north star for metric design: choose OEC components that causally predict user LTV, not just short-term lifts.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring long-term effects: holdouts and models
quotes.text: Yeah, so there's two ways that I like to think about it. One is you can run long-term experiments for the goal of learning something.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Introduces a simple two-part framework for measuring long-term effects, starting with intentionally longer experiments aimed at learning.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring long-term effects: holdouts and models
quotes.text: The other thing is you can just build models that use some of our background knowledge or use some data science to look at historical...
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Highlights modeling as the complementary approach to long holdouts for pricing in downstream costs using historical data and domain knowledge.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring long-term effects: holdouts and models
quotes.text: And the initial version was, whenever a user comes from the email and purchases something on Amazon, we're going to give that email credit. Well, it turned out this had no countervailing metric. The more emails you send, the more money you're going to credit the team. And so that led to spam.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A concrete cautionary example of how single-metric attribution creates perverse incentives and drives harmful behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring long-term effects: holdouts and models
quotes.text: But the point was, now we have this countervailing metric. We say, "Here's the money that we generate from the emails. Here's the money that we're losing on long-term value. What's the trade-off?" And then when we started to incorporate those formula, more than half the campaigns that were being sent were negative.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Shows an actionable methodology—add a countervailing metric for long-term cost—and the surprising result it can reveal at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring long-term effects: holdouts and models
quotes.text: We all love them. This is the humbling reality. And people talk about the fact that A/B testing sometimes leads you to incremental... I actually think that many of these small insights lead to fundamental insights about which areas to go, some strategies we should take, some things we should develop. Helps a lot.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Counters the common critique that A/B tests only yield incremental gains by arguing small learnings can drive major strategic direction.

quotes.topic_title: Why big redesigns fail and how to de-risk
quotes.text: So the right way to do this is to say, "Yes, we want to do a redesign, but let's do it in steps and test on the way and adjust," so you don't need to take 17 new changes, that many of them are going to fail. Start to move incrementally in a direction that you believe is beneficial. Adjust on the way.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A practical methodology for de-risking redesigns by breaking them into iterative, testable steps instead of bundling many changes at once.

quotes.topic_title: Why big redesigns fail and how to de-risk
quotes.text: So this is the other advantage of recognizing this humble reality that most ideas fail. If you believe in that statistics that I published, then doing 17 changes together is more likely to be negative. Do them in smaller increments, learn from, it's called OFAT one-factor-at-a-time. Do one factor, learn from it, and adjust. Of the 17, maybe you have four good ideas. Those are the ones that will launch and be positive.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Introduces OFAT (one-factor-at-a-time) as a concrete framework to isolate what works and avoid negative outcomes from bundled redesigns.

quotes.topic_title: Why big redesigns fail and how to de-risk
quotes.text: And I said, "I'm going to build an experimentation platform," because nobody at Microsoft is running experiments. And more than 50% of ideas in Amazon that we tried failed. And the classical response was, "We have better PMs here."
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A vivid example (and data point) showing how often ideas fail even at elite companies—and the common organizational denial that experimentation helps correct.

quotes.topic_title: Why big redesigns fail and how to de-risk
quotes.text: What I'm telling you is 80% of the time, you will fail. So be ready for that. What people usually expect is, "My redesign is going to work." No, you're most likely going to fail, but if you do succeed, it's a breakthrough.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive rule-of-thumb that reframes big redesigns as high-failure-rate bets that require explicit expectation-setting and risk management.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern growth team stack.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical constraint teams face: experimentation is necessary, but tooling often doesn’t fit modern workflows, creating execution friction.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This leads to wasted time building internal tools or trying to run your own experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Calls out a common operational failure mode that slows experimentation velocity and distracts teams from learning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved most about working there was our experimentation platform, where I was able to slice and dice data by device types, country, user stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of what “good” experimentation infrastructure enables: fast segmentation to diagnose effects across key dimensions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic click through metrics, and instead use your North Star metrics like activation, retention, subscription and payments.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable measurement guidance: optimize experiments against North Star outcomes rather than shallow proxy metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Is it ever worth just going, "Let's just rethink this whole thing and just give it a shot," to break out of a local minima or local maxima essentially?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a mental model from optimization: sometimes you need bigger, riskier changes to escape local optima rather than incremental tweaks.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb experimentation culture and Covid-era decisions
quotes.text: So I think actually in a state like that, it's even more important to run A/B tests, right? Because what you want to be able to see is if we're making this change, is it actually helping in the current environment?
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Contrary to the instinct to move fast without measurement in a crisis, he argues experimentation becomes more valuable to validate impact under new conditions.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb experimentation culture and Covid-era decisions
quotes.text: There's this idea of external generalizability. Is it going to work out now during Covid? Is it going to generalize later on? These are things that you can really answer with the controlled experiments, and sometimes it means that you might have to replicate them six months down when Covid say is not as impactful as it is.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Introduces a practical mental model—external generalizability—and the tactic of re-running experiments as environments shift.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb experimentation culture and Covid-era decisions
quotes.text: Saying that you have to make decisions quickly, to me, I'll point you to the success rate. If in peace time you're wrong two thirds to 80% of the time, why would you be subtly right in wartime, in Covid time?
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: Uses a striking base-rate argument to challenge the belief that urgency improves decision quality without experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb experimentation culture and Covid-era decisions
quotes.text: One is in my team in search relevance, everything was A/B tested. So while Brian can focus on some of the design aspects, the people who are actually doing the neural networks and the search, everything was A/B tested to hell. So nothing was launching without an A/B test.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A concrete example of an experimentation standard—no launches without tests—especially in high-impact algorithmic/search work.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb experimentation culture and Covid-era decisions
quotes.text: I think if Airbnb stayed the course, did nothing, the revenue would've gone up in the same way.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A provocative counterfactual claim that cautions against attributing recovery to reactive changes rather than underlying demand shifts.

quotes.topic_title: Writing the book and its reception
quotes.text: I was pleasantly surprised that it sold more than what we thought, more than what Cambridge predicted.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A concrete data point that challenges assumptions about how “niche” practitioner-focused technical topics can still reach a large audience.

quotes.topic_title: Writing the book and its reception
quotes.text: So when first we were approached by Cambridge after a tutorial that we did to write a book, I was like, "I don't know, this is too small of a niche area."
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that even experts often underestimate demand for clear, practical guidance in specialized domains.

quotes.topic_title: Writing the book and its reception
quotes.text: And we wrote a book that we thought is not statistically oriented, has fewer formulas than you normally see, and focuses on the practical aspects and on trust, which is the key.
quotes.speaker: Ronny Kohavi
quotes.context: A practical framework for communicating technical material: reduce unnecessary math, emphasize real-world application, and center “trust” as the core principle.
